title: top ten irritants summer heatwave jane moore
story: First and foremost being the Met Office’s “Amber Alert” warning to stay in the shade, drink plenty of fluids and be sure to wear sunscreen and dark glasses.Come winter, of course, they’ll once again be treating us all like morons and doom-mongering about slippery pavements and hypothermia.Luckily for them, new research revealing the top ten list of what irritates us came out before their nannying nonsense and, therefore, a “sorry we missed you” note took first place, followed by the whirring wheel on a computer and losing work you didn’t save.Life’s irritants, eh? Oh, let me count the ways. And believe me, it goes waaaay past ten.In fact, there are so many I feel it easier to group them together under various categories. So here goes.Eat with their mouths open stop an interesting group conversation to tell a dull, long-winded story with no point to it are overweight but claim they barely eat anything are thin but claim they eat everything pepper every, like, sentence with, like, the word “like” (Exhibit A: Anyone on Love Island) noisily slurp drinks in the cinema don’t pick up their dog’s poo make every sentence sound like a question litter the countryside don’t control their children in public places barge on to a train while you’re trying to get off read over your shoulder put bags on seats park in disabled bays when they’re clearly not live in a trillion quid mansion but claim to be socialist are glued to their mobile phone while their kid hurtles towards a road junction on its micro scooterupload ALL their holiday photos on social media, even the really crap ones say “aaah” loudly after drinking something.Aaaaaargh!Passengers who applaud when a flight lands parents who allow their kids to continually kick the back of your seat for the duration of a flight airport/rail managers who fail to boost staff numbers at peak times of the year oncoming drivers who push their way down a narrow road when you’re already three­quarters of the way along it train passengers who talk loudly on a mobile phone or think everyone else wants to listen to their ghastly music too people who cough on a crowded Tube/train without covering their mouth tailgaters drivers who don’t say thank you when you let them in middle lane hoggers packing hand luggage for a quick exit and being forced to put it in the hold.Head lice (so pointless) “Smart” TVs that make you feel anything but when trying to use the damned things novelty ringtones printed signs with spelling errors (use a pigging dictionary)online sites that won’t accept your usual password because it doesn’t have 48 squillion characters in it packaging that Harry Houdini would struggle to open roadworks with no one working on them spam emails automated phone systems immovable price stickers.Passing waiters who, when you ask for something simple like a spoon, reply: “Hang on, I’ll just get your waiter for you” shop assistants who stalk you around the rails as if you’re about to nick something fellow shoppers who start turning the rack of cards while you’re still looking at it hairdressers who chat incessantly through the supposedly “relaxing” head massage bit waiters who automatically hand the bill to the man queue-pushers at the bar bags “for life” that break the second you leave the supermarket assistants who carry on their social chat while you stand at the till waiting to be served cashiers who comment, “Ooh, are you having a party?”when you’re buying your own weekly wine supply shoppers who abuse the “ten items or less” aisle. Unless it’s me, of course.Believe me, I’m just scratching the surface here.Send me your irritations and I’ll print the best next week.Meghan Markles unpleasant half-sister Samantha is at it again – this time berating her understandably estranged royal relative for paying tribute to Nelson Mandela.“How about you pay tribute to your own father?” she ranted. “Enough is enough.Act like a humanitarian, act like a woman.If our father dies, I’m holding you responsible, Meg.”What a Grade A nasty.Meanwhile, last week Meghan’s father Thomas spent his 74th birthday picking up a Happy Meal from fast-food joint McDonald’s.Which, considering he’s just had heart stents fitted to help clear clogged arteries, suggests that if he dies any time soon, the only person responsible would be him.High-end designer ­Burberry junks £28million of unwanted products each year.A Burberry source has denied claims that they don’t donate it to charity because they don’t want the “wrong people” ­wearing it, saying that the destruction is actually to ­protect the brand against counterfeiting. Hmmm.The fakes ­market will always ­flourish irrespective of how many originals are pulped.So why doesn’t ­Burberry donate the items to upmarket charity ­auctions where people can bid a lot of money for something they might have bought anyway and have the extra thrill of knowing their cash will go to a deserving cause?Model David Gandy says he was once chucked out of a Hugo Boss catwalk show “because I couldn’t fit any of the clothing”.But luckily for the legion of Mr Gandy’s female fans, he can clearly still squeeze his, ahem, lardy self in to a teeny tiny pair of ­Y-fronts.Nope, still not going to wear them.Former Olympic showjumper Lizzie Purbrick has been telling her side of the story after being convicted of criminal damage for spraying her former lover’s home with several litres of pig’s blood.As you do.Lizzie, 63, says that initially, her relationship with Tory peer Lord Prior was “bloody marvellous” after they “met at a dinner party in Norfolk – the hotbed of sex – and I moved in with him four days later.”Whoa. Hang on, rewind that. Genteel Norfolk a hotbed of sex?And lo and behold, two days after this revelation, a survey by our sister paper The Sun on Sunday revealed that the nookie capital of Britain is…drum roll…Norfolk.So quite what they’re putting in the water up there is anyone’s guess.But something tells me house prices are suddenly set to rise.Charlie, 45, told his brother Matthew on the phone: “I’d really like to go out for a bottle of wine. I’ve been let out for a cigarette but I’m very bored.”We’ll take that as a no, then.Activity badges for Guides, Rangers and Brownies have been revamped for the 21st Century.You’ll be relieved to know Moped Mugging isn’t one of them, but there’s “Mixology” which involves designing a menu of non-alcoholic cocktails, “Festival Goer”, Vlogging, Mindfulness, Human Rights, Conscious ­Consumer and Media Critic (everyone’s a bloody critic.) Cripes.During my brief time as a Brownie in the late Sixties, I only achieved the “Hostess” badge, which entailed making a cup of tea for some visiting dignitaries at our local community centre and helping an elderly woman across the road.She didn’t want to go but, hey, a badge is a badge.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: hostile eu uk daniel hannan opinion
story: Most Britons, whether they voted Remain or Leave, hoped that we would replace EU ­membership with a close alliance.Pulling out of the Brussels institutions did not need to prejudice friendly relations with our neighbours.But it is becoming clear that Eurocrats do not see it that way. The 27 EU states, or most of them at any rate, might individually want good relations with us.But, in Brussels, there are plenty of officials who would rather see all sides suffer than watch Brexit succeed.If their view prevails, the implications go well beyond Brexit. For 70 years, Britain has been a European power.Although we kept our military ties with the other English-speaking democracies, our focus was the defence of Europe. It still is.There are, for example, British soldiers patrolling the borders of Poland and Estonia.The RAF is, to all intents and purposes, acting as Romania’s air force, responding to incursions into that country’s airspace. And so on.In intelligence and security, rather as with the Common Fisheries Policy, Britain puts a lot more than its share into the common pot.We have done so cheerfully because we saw European states as our allies, and felt that we had a stake in their security. But what if that feeling is no longer reciprocated?Visiting Germany on Monday, Jeremy Hunt, the Foreign Secretary, pointed out in measured and polite language that the EU could not expect to treat Britain aggressively without consequences.Now Mr Hunt is no Little Englander. He is an entrepreneur who made his money from language courses, is married to a Chinese woman and, after some soul-searching, came down on the side of Remain.But what he said is impossible to argue with. If the EU chooses to treat Brexit as a hostile act, the basis of European security will be undone — at the very moment that Donald Trump has made it clear that America is no longer interested in defending Europe.In almost every European speech since the referendum, Theresa May has said that she wants Britain to be the EU’s closest friend and strongest ally.But when have you ever heard those good wishes returned?The PM keeps saying she wants the EU 27 to succeed. EU leaders keep saying they want Brexit to fail.They mean it. Eurocrats are not offering Britain the kind of deal that they have with neighbours such as Norway and Switzerland.They think UK will just swallow what’s offered.If we want to remain in the single market, says chief EU negotiator Michel Barnier, then, unlike those countries, we’d have to give Brussels 100 per cent control of our trade policy — an impossible condition.But neither are they offering the kind of simple free trade deal that they have with, say, Canada and Japan.If we want a straightforward trade deal, Barnier says, we’d have to leave Northern Ireland under EU rules — an equally impossible condition.In other words, Britain won’t be allowed the friendly relations with the EU that other democracies take for granted.It is not for a lack of willingness on our side. In February, Theresa May told a Munich audience: “Europe’s security is our security. And that is why I say that the United Kingdom is unconditionally committed to maintaining it.”The EU’s response? To exclude us from the Galileo satellite programme on grounds that we could no longer be trusted.Well, fine. I never saw much point in the Galileo system, which was pushed by French leader Jacques Chirac to challenge the “technological imperialism” of America’s GPS system.Britain should now either go in with the Americans or create its own satellite system, possibly with friendly states such as Australia and Canada.But the point is, the EU’s logic goes well beyond satellites.If Brussels no longer sees us as an ally, we can hardly carry on behaving like one unilaterally, so to speak.While we talk of trade and co-operation, EU negotiators talk of border queues and grounded flights.Ireland’s prime minister, Leo Varadkar, even threatens to close his airspace.If such thinking wins out, we shall have no choice but to leave Europe to itself and turn our faces, as our ancestors did, to the open seas.That is not an outcome anyone should want, but we shall be ready if it comes.Understandably enough, you might say, given what feeble negotiators we have been so far. But Britain has a bad habit of switching from vague amiability to sudden resolve when it is almost too late.Such a moment is upon us.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: the met office can stick advice where sun doesnt shine let us enjoy the heat while it lasts
story: You get a lovely chill from the cotton. OK, later you might find a hash brown stuck halfway up your bottom, but it’s worth it, just for the pleasantly cool sensation.It’s been a lovely summer, the best that I can remember since 1976. That summer was the happiest time of my life. But this hasn’t been bad, has it?But there are downsides to the driest and warmest spell we’ve had for years.Public transport isn’t always much fun, especially if you’re crunched up on the Tube next to a large bearded lady who last washed when hula hoops were all the rage.If you live in the country, there are mosquitoes — I’ve got bites in ­places I ­forgot existed.Work can be a bit of a chore. And if you’re a smoker, the pub gardens are suddenly full of tossers who waft their hands around if the smoke goes anywhere near them.Where were you when it was snowing, huh? I was there, lighting my Superking in a blizzard, while you were tucked away inside.But the hot weather is very good for us.There’s a link between clear, sunny days and good health — mental as well as physical.People feel better about themselves and tend to spend more money, which is good for the economy.OK, crime rates tend to increase when the weather is hot — more precisely, when the temperature ­hovers between 28C and 32C, according to psychologists.But on the whole, this summer — a proper summer, at last — is something to be enjoyed, cherished and remembered. We don’t have them very often.We can admire the women walking around with not many clothes on and laugh at the men dressed in toddler shorts with beer bellies hanging down to their knees.We can relax with a beer and forget about bloody Brexit for a while.The authorities think of nice summers as altogether something very different.For them, nice summers are a crisis.That’s why those tiresome drongos at the Met Office put out an amber alert when the temperature rose this week.“Don’t go out! Stay in your homes! Or you will die — DIE, I tell you.”Oh, with the greatest respect — f*** off!We’ll go out when and where we please, thank you, so you can stuff your advice where the sun isn’t shining.And, of course, the climate change ­monkeys are in full voice.“This is it! The end of the world! Look at the incredible temperatures and those wildfires in poor Greece. We told you!”Give it a rest. I think there is something to global warming. I am not a denier. But I remember the last few ­summers we’ve had — rainy and cool — and the climate change monkeys saying THAT was a consequence of global ­warming, too. You can’t have it both ways.And there have been wildfires in hot, dry areas for the past 100,000 years.So enjoy this wonderful heatwave while you can. Because someday, quite soon, it will be gone and the rain and the cold will be back, and the Christmas adverts will start appearing in supermarkets.And this summer will just be ­something you talk about in years to come. Remember the summer of 2018? Wasn’t it brilliant? If only we could have it again.Carlos Delacruz was in court in Scotland accused of having sex with two women with something other than a penis.The lasses THOUGHT it was his todger. But then, the lights were off.And the sad truth is that Mr Delacruz does not have a penis. Not even a small one.The women complained the sex was painful. So what was it, then?It was referred to in court as an “unknown object”.Here are my guesses:Incidentally, the prosecuting lawyer was called Ms Cockburn.No kidding, love.NO sooner has the World Cup finished than the domestic football season is about to begin.And with it the endless round of transfer speculation.If you’re still wondering why England didn’t win the World Cup, check out how many top foreign teams are trying to buy our players.None. None whatsoever.All the sides we played against in the final stages had players at Juventus, Real Madrid, Barcelona, Bayern Munich etc.That’s because they are very good players.But none of the top European clubs wants Harry or Dele or Raheem.We are a lot further behind than many people think.LABOUR MP and fervent Brexiteer Kate Hoey received the following email from a man called Robert Crangle.“I have never written to an MP before. I just want to say that you are a f***ing disgrace for helping to keep the Tories in power. I hope you die soon.”Lefty Remainers are a lovely bunch, aren’t they?IS it actually the law that all pop musicians must end up skagged out of their heads and taken to hospital?And then, if they survive, check into some poncey rehab clinic and tell their fans they are “fighting my demons”.And then come out of rehab and get skagged out of their heads again.The latest is Demi Lovato.I must admit I’m not a huge fan, but still.First time we knew anything was amiss was when she forgot the lyrics to one of her songs. title: man allergic sun
story: Though he was initially sent home from hospital with a supposed infection, shockingly it later transpired that he was allergic to the sun.This rare condition is known as Xeroderma Pigmentosum and only 100 people in the UK have been diagnosed with it. It causes skin to blister and burn if it is exposed to the slightest amount of UV light.Understandably getting on with daily routines had been a real struggle for Alex, 25.Every inch of his skin had to be covered to stop it from burning. To protect his face his mum, Anna, designed and made a thick visor from plastic that hung from a hat and covered his face – but it was incredibly hot and distorted his vision.As part of a new TV experiment airing tonight, Inventing the Impossible: The Big Life, three people with various medical conditions hope to have their world transformed by a group of inventors. Alex, who also has neurological complications which have led to hearing loss and learning difficulties says: I wish I could be like everyone else but I cant help not being that.Design engineer Zoe Laughlin was challenged with to come up with a better solution to Alexs large and clunky homemade visor.But because Alex is 10,000 times more sensitive to UV damage than a normal person - so much so that even on gloomy days, he can’t go out unprotected - the requirements were extensive.He has to check the lights in every room with a special UV protection device wherever he goes.Anna says: “While a normal person’s DNA repairs at a rate of 98 per cent, his repairs at just 3 per cent. So if I was to get cancer at 60, he’d be likely to get it at three.“The doctors told us we’d have to live by night and sleep by day. So for the first few years we lived with the curtains closed.“I’d sit inside every day and cry with him. And the rest of the world went on outside.“But doctors said he might die at three and I wanted to show him as much of the world as I could. I wasn’t prepared to lock him away.Using a UV testing meter and a UV light, the engineers set to work to test different materials to see what might work as a base material for a mask to protect Alexs skin.Glass, snorkel masks and plastic all proved too weak and let UV rays through - which would cause Alex to burn.It turns out that Zoes moment of inspiration occurred while on a spa break.After trying a peel-off mask, the lead engineer tracked down a prosthetics company to see if they could make a UV protecting mask - like that used in Ninteties hit film Mrs Doubtfire.The idea was that it would be a second skin, which Alex could put on whenever he wants to leave the house.The mask was made by taking a scan of the persons face using a flashing light camera that takes thousands and thousands of pictures per seconds. The code of these photos is then sent to a computer and a 3D mask is created in the right proportions for the customers face.She finds a special kind of silicone that has 100 per cent UV protection.Dubious at first, Alex agrees to let Zoe and the other engineers go ahead and make the mask for him and undergoes a 3D body scan. It creates a lifelike 3D model of him which is then printed and cast back in the workshop.Using a bed of polymer powder, they print an exact model of Alex that will form the basis of the mask. A mould is then filled with the silicone.The mask took more than 300 painstaking hours to create - but once it is ready, Zoe takes the finished piece - complete with artificial stubble and hair - to Alex.Clearly unsure and shocked, the 25-year-old agrees to try it on, admitting hes blown away by the similarity between his face and the masks.Anna says: Im so glad they tried something that hasnt been done before. I just didnt think that you could do it. Theres a lot of work gone into it.Trying it on, Alex is speechless.Its so much more comfortable, he finally says, walking round in the mask of his own face.Without hesitating, Alex takes his first steps outside in his new mask.His mum, clearly emotional, say: Ive never seen Alex like this in my life.Alex hasnt been out like this, in broad daylight, at midday, ever, Anna says. Its a whole new world of potential.

title: women age two years for every pregnancy due to changes in dna research reveals
story: Cell changes in pregnancy may have a lasting negative impact, they found.Each child could slash the mum’s life expectancy and make poor health more likely.The US researchers studied cells taken from 821 women aged 20 to 22 who had up to five kids.Those with most offspring had DNA with shorter protective ­telomeres and more of another marker that both indicate genetic ageing.The changes are linked to a shorter lifespan and ill health.Analysis found that each birth increased a mother’s cellular age by six months to two years.Yet her cells looked temporarily younger during pregnancy and she may have a glow that makes her appear more youthful.Study leader Calen Ryan, from Northwestern University in Chicago, said he was surprised by the scale of the ageing.He added: “The markers independently predict mortality and both appeared older in women who have had more pregnancies.“Even accounting for other factors that affect cell ageing, pregnancy numbers still came top.”His colleague Prof Christopher Kuzawa wants research to see if the changes persist in older age.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: decades of heatwaves 37c friday
story: Temperatures of 99F are set to make this the hottest July day on record, with the searing heatwave expected to last throughout August. And it is possible that today might even beat the record UK high of 101F.As the nation sweated yesterday, it emerged that red-hot summers may become an annual event.Professor Peter Stott, of the Met Office, said: “Since 1976, global temperatures have increased significantly. The risk of extreme heatwaves is increasing rapidly worldwide due to greenhouse gas emissions.“This summer we are seeing an expression of that increased risk. It’s human-induced climate change that has made such a situation as we’ve seen in 2018 more likely.” The current heatwave began on June 24 and is the longest since the drought of 1976.Widespread thunderstorms, showers and even hail storms are predicted for today, but the ­sweltering heat is then expected to return.STUFFY bosses at Lord’s have relaxed their strict dress code to allow men to go without a jacket.Marylebone Cricket Club, which owns the ground in North West London, said visitors to the pavilion would be spared during the heatwave.The club tweeted: “This applies to members and their guests.”Normal rules state that men visiting the pavilion on match days must wear lounge suits or tailored blazer and trousers. They are also expected to sport a shirt, tie or cravat and shoes with socks.Lord’s hosted a Middlesex v Hampshire Vitality Blast match last night. The England v India Test match will be played there from August 9 to 13.BRITAIN will sizzle in 99F (37.2C) today — hotter than all of Europe.The record baker beats holiday favourites such as the south of France, Majorca and Italy, and leaves our continental chums wondering if they should escape to the sun here.The highest July temperature, 98F (36.7C) set in 2015 at Heathrow, could be burned away today.Also under threat is the UK record of 101F (38.5C) set in Faversham, Kent, on August 10, 2003.Millions are expected to bunk off work to enjoy the fry-day scorcher.Afternoon storms will briefly halt the heatwave, with some parched areas seeing their first rain in two months.Flash flooding and power cuts are possible.Cooler weekend temperatures will be followed by the return of 91F (33C) highs.Paul Gundersen, Met Office chief meteorologist, said: “We could break the all-time record on Friday if conditions all come together.“We will also see intense storms affecting many central and eastern areas, with as much as an inch of rain in an hour and 2.5ins in three hours. Large hail and strong winds are likely.”Colleague Simon Partridge added: “We’ll go into next week with more high pressure building.“After a very brief pause it will be very much as you were.”Last night, millions struggled to sleep as the mercury stayed a stifling 70F (21C) in London and the South East. Today many are set to swap the office in favour of beaches, parks and boozers.Economist Howard Archer said: “Workers will bunk off entirely or take an extended lunch and stay in the pub.“On the positive side, there will be a boost in retail sales of everything from sunglasses to sun cream, food and drink. “There may even be a boost to tourism with people opting for a last-minute staycation instead of a holiday abroad.”Some have bragged about the increase in social media posts.Doctors say it is “summer penis”, caused by blood vessels expanding in the heat.GP Sa­rah Jarvis said: “When surface blood vessels are bigger, things will look a bit bigger.”Rail lines are at risk of buckling and overhead power lines could start to sag.Services on Chiltern Railways, Northern and Greater Anglia are expected to be worst-hit today.Network Rail said engineers and extreme weather teams were monitoring track-side temperatures and vulnerable locations. A spokesman said: “We will, if necessary, introduce temporary speed restrictions in the hottest part of the day to keep trains running.”The nation’s roads are also melting with surface temperatures topping 122F (50C).Gritters have been scrambled to spread sand to stop the bitumen from sticking to tyres.Leicestershire County Council said its fleet had spread 150 tonnes of granite this month. And the A30 in Somerset was shut both ways after its resurfaced road failed to cool in time.A swimmer in his 20s who went for a dip in the Jubilee River near Slough, Berks, on Wednesday was found dead by divers yesterday.Coastguards were searching for a boy thought to have made a “tombstoning” jump near Clacton pier, Essex, at 6.20pm last night.Another teenage boy was rescued from the water.And a girl was airlifted to hospital in a serious condition after currents swept her out to sea off the Isle of Sheppey, Kent.Highways England has warned drivers are fuelling fires by chucking cigarette butts out of windows.The heat and emissions from the continent led to a high air pollution alert in London.The capital’s fire brigade is also calling for a temporary ban on barbecues in public spaces after a spate of blazes.NHS trusts are seeing record numbers of people at A&ampE for respiratory problems and conditions made worse by dehydration.There were 230,611 visits to the NHS Choices advice webpage for heat exhaustion this month, quadruple the amount last July.Saffron Cordery, of NHS Providers, said: “There is no let-up in the pressure on services.”EUROTUNNEL cancelled thousands of tickets yesterday after “extreme temperatures” caused major disruption.The cross-Channel rail operator halted day or overnight trips after air conditioning units failed on trains.The move was an attempt to ease long queues after passengers faced delays of up to six-and-a-half hours.The English end of the Folkestone-Calais link was worst hit, with travellers forced to queue for 90 minutes just to check in and a further five hours for a train. Passengers were urged to stock up with drinking water before arrival.In one of the busiest weeks of the year for cross-Channel travel as school holidays start, traffic queues stretched back to the M20.Meanwhile, motorists heading for the Lake District could face long delays in sweltering heat today if a closure for repairs to an M6 bridge hit by a lorry continues near Preston.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: half of the uks electricity in 2017 came from low carbon sources such as wind turbines and nuclear power
story: Renewables including wind, solar, biomass and hydropower provided a record 29.3% of Britains electricity in 2017, up from just under a quarter the previous year, as more wind turbines and solar farms were put up.Half of the power from renewables came from offshore wind farms, which generated 6.2% of overall power, and onshore turbines, which provided 8.6%.There was a shift away from coal and gas towards renewables, with coals share of electricity generation falling to just 6.7% and gas power dropping to 40.4% of the mix, the annual Digest of UK Energy Statistics (Dukes) said.In total, low carbon energy sources accounted for a record 50.1% of UK electricity last year, up from 45.6% in 2016, the figures from the Business and Energy Department revealed.The shift away from fossil fuels for generating power meant that overall carbon emissions fell by 3.2% between 2016 and 2017.The amount of pollution for each unit of electricity produced has more than halved in five years, down from 483 grams of carbon dioxide per kilowatt hour of electricity in 2012 to 225g in 2017.Industry body RenewableUKs executive director, Emma Pinchbeck, said: Todays record figures demonstrate how fast renewable energy is transforming the way we generate power to create an energy system fit for the future.This is a radical shift, and we will see ever more low-cost renewables meeting flexible demand from homes, electric vehicles and new manufacturing processes and industries.She added: Its great to see that the UKs cheapest power source, onshore wind, is making such a significant contribution to the nations power needs.So its baffling that the Government is still excluding new onshore wind projects from the market place.Opinion polls show that two thirds of people think ministers should change their current policy and allow onshore wind to go ahead where it has local support, and most Conservative voters agree with them.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: major brexit blow theresa eu
story: NewsMajor Brexit blow to Theresa May as EU chief Michel Barnier flatly rejects her customs planBut after a day of negotiations with Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab, Brussels chief negotiator Michel Barnier unceremoniously killed the ideaShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByMikey SmithPolitical reporter17:11, 26 JUL 2018News (Image: REX/Shutterstock)Get politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTheresa May’s Brexit plan was dealt a major blow today, as the EU flatly rejected her suggestion for a customs deal. The Prime Minister’s Chequers proposals suggested a situation where the UK would collect excise duties at the border on the EU’s behalf.  But after a day of negotiations with Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab, Brussels chief negotiator Michel Barnier unceremoniously killed the idea.  At a press conference following the day’s negotiations, he said: “The EU cannot and will not delegate its customs policy and rules, VAT and excise duty collections to a non member who would not be subject to the EU’s governance structures. “Any customs arrangements or customs union - and I’ve always said the EU is open to a customs union - must respect this principle. “And in any case, a customs union, which would help to reduce friction at the border, would come with our common policy for goods.”  He added: “The UK wants to take back control of its money, law and borders, and we will respect that, But the EU also wants to keep control of its money, law and borders and the UK should respect that. Mr Barnier said that he wanted to bring new energy into these negotiations over the coming weeks ahead of the EU summit in October at which it is hoped to finalise the Withdrawal Agreement and reach a political declaration on a future relationship. He said that UK proposals on security marked a real step forward and welcomed the acknowledgement in Mrs May's White Paper that the European Court of Justice is the only arbiter of EU law. He said he was particularly pleased with progress on foreign policy and external security. But he said: In contrast, on our future economic relationship, it comes as no surprise that finding common ground between the EU27 and the UK is more difficult.  Mr Barnier said future market access for financial services would be governed by autonomous decisions on both sides. We recognise the need for this autonomy not only at the time of granting equivalence decisions but also at the time of withdrawing such decisions and we agreed to have close regulatory cooperation, he said. And he said the backstop on the Irish border must be resolved and raised concerns about the UK's position.

title: march against modern destitution footsteps
story: NewsopinionMarch against modern destitution in footsteps of brave Blanketeers who were the working poor of their dayEach of the destitute ‘Blanketeers’ carried a blanket, to show they were textile workers and to sleep in during their wintry journeyShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByRos Wynne JonesReal Britain columnist00:15, 27 JUL 2018Updated00:19, 27 JUL 2018NewsopinionThree artists from Manchester will follow the Blanketeers’ route to London (Image: John-Paul Brown)Get politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailOn March 10, 1817, 5,000 Lancashire spinners and weavers and thousands of onlookers gathered at St Peter’s Fields, Manchester, to set out for London. Each of the destitute ‘Blanketeers’ carried a blanket, to show they were textile workers and to sleep in during their wintry journey. They also carried a letter to the Prince Regent. “We will let them see it is not riot and disturbance we want,” the &shyLancashire reformer Samuel &shyDrummond told the crowds. “It is bread we want, and we will apply to our noble Prince as a child would to its Father for bread.” Beaten back by the King’s Dragoon Guards, the Blanketeers were the forerunners of the tens of thousands who gathered at St Peter’s Fields two years later, only to be charged by cavalry. On that hot August day in 1819 – a turning point in Britain’s social history that is the subject of Mike Leigh’s latest film Peterloo – 15 people including a young child died, and up to 700 people were injured.  On Sunday, three artists from Manchester will follow the Blanketeers’ route to London, carrying blankets made by Lauren Sagar, 59, an award-winning artist. For Sagar, and her fellow travellers – Eve Robertson, 41, an actor and director, and John-Paul Brown, 36, a photographer and sculptor – their modern-day march is about the pain of austerity and the way gentrification drives artists and working class people out of cities. “The story of the Blanketeers seems to be fairly unknown, even to people who know about The Peterloo Massacre,” Sagar says. “They were self-employed spinners and weavers facing the loss of their jobs and poor working conditions. They were destitute. “They each carried a small piece of the petition for the Prince Regent, which they planned to put together when they got there. As soon as they set off, they were read the Riot Act and faced violence and intimidation. One man was killed and the story has it that only one man, Abel Cauldwell, made it to London. When I read about it I was inspired by their bravery, walking into the unknown, people who might not have left home before. “They wanted to let people know what was happening and the importance of that story really struck me. Blankets are something we all need, something basic and fundamentally human, and like the original Blanketeers, we’ll carry ones, created by me.”

story: NewsopinionVoice of the Mirror: Tory boasts of being the party of law and order look increasingly threadbareA combination of austerity and incompetence has left the prison and probation services on their knees and the latest statistics should be a matter of national shameShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByVoice of the Mirror00:12, 27 JUL 2018NewsopinionOne in 10 prisons is now rated “a serious concern” (Image: iStockphoto)Get politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe Tories used to boast they were the party of law and order. story: NewsFalkland Islands become first overseas British territory to vote in support of assisted dyingPoliticians passed a motion that terminally ill residents should have the right to end their life, subject to proper safeguardsShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByAmy-Clare Martin23:37, 26 JUL 2018Updated23:40, 26 JUL 2018NewsThe islands’ Legislative Assembly also voted to consider changing laws if the UK first did the same (Image: Getty)Get daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe Falkland Islands has become the first overseas British territory to vote in support of assisted dying. Politicians passed a motion that terminally ill residents should have the right to end their life, subject to proper safeguards. The islands’ Legislative Assembly also voted to consider changing laws if the UK first did the same. Both motions passed by a majority of four votes to three, with one abstention. Although laws are not changing on the South Atlantic islands, campaigners hope the show of support will lead the way for other areas. The assembly chair will write to the Prime Minister to say if the UK enacts legislation allowing people to end their lives legally, the Falkland Islands would consider following suit.  The news follows a shock defeat on a bill legalising assisted dying in Guernsey. Proposals were rejected by 24 votes to 16 after three days of debate on the Channel island in May. However pro-assisted dying campaigners say the vote acted as ‘driving force for change’ - inspiring motions in the Falklands and ramping up debate in Jersey. Sarah Wootton, chief executive of Dignity in Dying, said: “The Falkland Islands have today been shown to be a compassionate, sensible and progressive society which cares deeply about its terminally ill citizens and rightly feels that they deserve better.” A Mirror poll last month found three out of four Britons would support a change in the law to allow assisted dying.

title: girl 5 worst chicken pox
story: NewsGirl, 5, with the 'worst chicken pox doctors had ever seen' turned away from A&E twiceWARNING:DISTRESSING IMAGES Evie-Beth Taylor was just five when she stunned doctors at Darlington Memorial Hospital with her severe chicken poxShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByJessica Cripps10:37, 26 JUL 2018Updated22:49, 26 JUL 2018NewsEvie-Beth Taylor was just five when she flummoxed doctors with chickenpox so bad they initially told her parents it might be a rare genetic disease (Image: Kennedy News and Media)Get daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA mum has released horrifying images of her little girl with the 'worst chicken pox' her doctors had ever seen - yet she was turned away from A&ampE twice. Evie-Beth Taylor was just five when she flummoxed doctors with chickenpox so bad they initially told her parents it might be a rare genetic disease and not the childhood disease at all. The infection was so severe the little girl was left screaming in pain whenever she was touched making it impossible for mum Lianne Taylor, 33, to clean her airways. So poorly she couldn't eat, drink or even use the toilet, poor Evie-Beth's nose became so clogged with 'rock hard' mucus that the little girl struggled to breathe. Lianne called paramedics and her poorly daughter was rushed to A&ampE twice in just two days.  But Lianne claims she was 'treated like an over the top parent' and turned away both times, claiming she was told that she had to wait 10 days for the antibiotics prescribed by her GP to work. Desperate, Lianne took her daughter back to the GP once more who immediately arranged for her to go straight to hospital - where doctors told Lianne she was lucky to have brought her in when she did. After four days in hospital Evie-Beth was finally allowed to return home but it took months for the spots to completely go and has been left with scarring across her face and body. But now a year on, Lianne and Evie-Beth are bravely sharing the shocking images of her ordeal to raise awareness of just how serious chickenpox can be and tell other parents to seek help if concerned. Lianne, from Newton Aycliffe, County Durham, said: It was really traumatic seeing Evie-Beth like this.  She was struggling to breathe because she was so blocked up with mucus that went really hard. We couldn't get near her to wash her down or clean it away because she was screaming in pain. The spots just kept coming and coming. Even when she was in hospital the doctors were coming in every day and she was coming out with more and more spots. The doctors said they had never seen chickenpox that bad. They had a photographer come in and take photos of her skin because they had never seen a case as bad as hers before. They didn't know why. Mum-of-two Lianne first noticed a spot on her daughter's arm on February 4 2017 and thought it could be chickenpox. When the infection broke out in spots all over her body on February 8, her worried mum and dad Stuart Taylor bathed her in a bath with oats and rubbed her with creams and camomile lotions to ease the itch. But their daughter only got worse.  Lianne started sleeping in the same bed as little Evie-Beth so she could wake her up every hour to give her a drink. She was devastated when Evie-Beth only got more and more lethargic and eventually had to be carried and held over the toilet because her spots were too painful for her to even sit. Her GP prescribed her with antibiotics - but when paramedics took Evie-Beth to A and E on Feb 10 they turned her away then and on Feb 11 and told Lianne to wait 10 days for them to take effect. It wasn't until her GP sent Evie-Beth straight to Darlington Memorial Hospital on February 13 that the little girl was finally admitted. Lianne, who studies history at Teesside University, said: It was absolutely awful. It was really bad. Being sent away from A and E made me feel like I was treated like an over the top parent. It made it feel like it was beyond me and I couldn't do this. This was beyond the help I could give her. She couldn't eat or drink, she just lay there. She was crying and moaning and every time she moved she screamed. I was having to sleep next to her every night and not having much sleep myself and having to set an alarm to wake myself up every hour to get some fluids in her throat and give her paracetamol every four hours. It was horrendous. It was a really tough time.  I took her in the car to the doctor's and it took the GP to see her in pain to phone A and E and get her straight in at Darlington Hospital. They said this is really bad, any later and it would have been a different situation. They took her bloods and put her in isolation. The consultant sat us down and said it might not be chickenpox but could be a very rare genetic disease. They were going to have to transfer her over to Durham hospital where they could test her for it. It was very worrying. We got her across to Durham where consultants came in confirmed it was chicken pox but they didn't know why it was so bad. She was severely dehydrated. She'd lost loads of weight because she still wasn't eating, and she would go to the toilet in a bedpan because we couldn't get her to the toilet. The doctors gave her some antiviral medication on a drip. Eventually, she did have to go on to normal painkillers. They were coming and checking her vitals all the time. I slept in a room with her for those days when she was really bad. The hospital staff were fantastic though and got her a TV and DVD player and toys for her to play with when she was feeling a bit better.

title: grim state uks bus routes
story: NewsGrim state of UK's bus routes revealed as figures point to 28-year lowThe dire situation could get worse with even more routes under threat as Tory cuts bite deeper into town hall budgetsShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByMark Ellis23:36, 26 JUL 2018NewsThe UK bus network has shrunk by 8% in a decade (Image: Getty)Get daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email2Bus routes are disappearing almost as fast as railways in the 1960s under the Beeching cuts. They are already at levels not seen since the 1980s, leaving many people isolated and cut off from towns and cities. And the dire situation could get worse with even more routes under threat as Tory cuts bite deeper into town hall budgets. Public transport campaigners and Mirror readers say people are being left unable to reach their doctors’ surgeries and shops. In the 1960s, thousands of miles of track were scrapped and hundreds of stations closed after a report by British Railways boss Dr Richard Beeching. It could be the same for bus routes. Chris Todd, of the Campaign for Better Transport, said: “We are not talking a loss of that level but we are heading that way.”  The UK bus network has shrunk by 8% in a decade. That equates to 134 million fewer miles, the equivalent of more than 5,000 trips around the equator. Department for Transport figures also paint a grim picture, putting bus routes at a 28-year low with 1.5 billion miles travelled last year. Every day, almost 2.5 million people all over Britain travel to work by bus and a million more use the bus as a vital back-up. But since 2010, the Tories have nearly halved funding in England by &pound182million, fares have gone up by 13% above inflation and 3,347 routes have been axed or reduced.  The Mirror revealed yesterday how mum-of-nine Gemma Headley, 36, of Driffield, East Yorks, has to walk seven miles to get her two young daughters to infant school because of bus cuts. But many more people are being affected by the savage cuts. Life-long Mirror reader Brian Newbold, 76, of High Ercall, a village near Telford in Shropshire, uses buses to get to Shrewsbury every day. But in September, the Saturday service will be axed. The retired lecturer said getting out on the bus helped him cope with the death of wife Edith in 2001. He added: “Losing the Saturday service might not seem much but it is important to me.” Experts say there is an alternative — investing in bus travel and reaping the benefits as people return to towns and cities to spend their money. Earlier this month, the Mirror revealed analysis for Greener Journeys by auditors KPMG LLP shows that targeted investment to improve bus services would typically generate &pound3.32 of net economic benefit for each &pound1 spent.  Experts say for every &pound1 spent on concessionary travel schemes used by older and disabled people &pound2.87 is generated in benefits. Pass users have easier access to shops and healthcare as well as other services and activities plus visits to family and friends. The report adds: “With more freedom to travel, older people are more able to contribute as volunteers, as mentors, event organisers and fundraisers. They have new opportunities to look after children and to care for others. Free bus passes encourage older people to be more active and they have better health.” By 2037, the number of people in England aged over 60 will grow from 12 million to 18 million and campaigners say this will make the case for concessionary passes even stronger.

title: katy perrys costume designer unveils
story: NewsKaty Perry's costume designer unveils dresses made from WHIPPED MILKThe three dresses were created by designer Kate Tabor and took her over three weeks to makeShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByJack Peat17:03, 26 JUL 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay nowGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA collection of dresses made out of whipped milk have been unveiled by Katy Perry’s costume designer. The three dresses were created by designer Kate Tabor and took her over three weeks to make, using 20 metres of wetsuit material and 12 litres of foam.  Tabor took inspiration from the structural designs of Alexander McQueen and renowned haute-couturier Iris Van Herpen in creating the lip-smacking gowns.  The Couture creations were commissioned to celebrate the launch of Costa Coffee’s new Whipped Milk, which gives iced coffee drinks like the Iced Flat White and Cold Brew a silky mouth-feel while topping them with an elegant meringue-like appearance.  Kate Tabor, designer said: “Each dress is bespoke from a flirty minidress to an edgy asymmetric design and a classic, full-length bridal number all were inspired by the texture of Whipped Milk and the way it is poured. “I’ve created innovative costumes for everyone from David Bowie to The Chemical Brothers, but I’ve never designed anything as challenging or unique as Costa Coffee’s Whipped Milk Couture.” Designer Kate, who has created awe-inspiring costumes for music videos for the likes of Katy Perry and Kylie Minogue, began the process by sketching designs, then experimenting with delicate foams ahead of crafting robust neoprene shells, which supported the overall structure of the dresses. The painstaking application process took three hours per gown. The Whipped Milk creations mark the reinvention of Costa Coffee’s Iced Flat White and Iced Cappuccino drinks this summer.  The addition of Whipped Milk, an aerated skimmed milk foam topping, also forms the finishing flourish on summer menu items such as refreshing Cold Brew and in Costa Coffee’s new range of Milk Whips. Gennaro Pelliccia, Costa Coffee's Master of Coffee, added: Whipped Milk is Costa Coffee’s must-have summer drink addition, inviting coffee-lovers to enjoy their favourite hot choices as refreshing chilled drinks, perfect for the scorching weather we’ve been enjoying. “Coffee fans don’t even have to wait for Whipped Milk to make it from the catwalk to the high street, it’s already whipping up a storm in store now!” The Iced Flat White is expertly handcrafted by Costa Coffee's skilled baristas using the purest extract of the coffee bean.  In the same way the traditional ‘hot Flat White’ that fans know and love is finished with texturised milk so too is the iced version using the chilled Whipped Milk to recreate the luxurious silky texture. Cappuccino drinkers can enjoy the Iced Cappuccino made with either a double or triple extraction of espresso and topped with the delicate chilled milk foam. For a twist on your favourite Costa Cold Brew, try the Cold Brew with Whipped Milk. The meringue-like Whipped Milk floats beautifully on top of the Cold Brew and is a great way to add milk to the drink without diluting the coffee flavour and adding visual and sensorial excitement to the coffee drinking experience.

title: who imran khan how cricket
story: NewsWho is Imran Khan? How cricket legend became Prime Minister of PakistanSporting legend Khan has declared victory in Pakistan's general electionShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByAndrew SnellHomepage Editor15:27, 26 JUL 2018Updated16:20, 26 JUL 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay nowGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Pakistan cricket icon Imran Khan has declared victory in the race to be the country's next Prime Minister.  It is the crowning political achievement for a man who made his name not as a statesman but as a sporting hero. Since finishing his sporting career as one of the world's most famous cricketers, he has become an outspoken campaigner against political corruption. And on Thursday he declared victory in Pakistan's general elections - just 22 years after founding his political party. Here's everything you need to know about his journey from cricket star to world leader.  Imran Khan's cricket career  Khan was born in October 1952 in Lahore, Pakistan . He started his schooling at the private Aitchison school in Lohore, and later attended the Royal Grammar School, Worcester.  He completed an undergraduate degree in economics at Keble College, Oxford. He first started playing cricket for his college at the age of 13, and would later play for Worcestershire. He made his debut for Pakistan in 1971 at the age of 18, and by 1982 had become the national team's captain. Khan is commonly regarded as one of the greatest ever fast bowlers. In a glittering career he played 88 Test matches and scored 3807. He retired from cricket after winning the World Cup in 1992 as one of Pakistan’s all-time most successful players.  How did Imran Khan become Pakistan's Prime Minister? After his retirement from cricket, Khan became more focused on politics. In 1996 he founded the political party Pakistan Tehreek-e-Insaf (PTI), a centrist party opposed to the centre-left Pakistan People's Party (PPP) and conservative Pakistan Muslim League (PML). Khan went on hunger strike in 2007 as a protest against emergency rule in Pakistan. It came a week after he was jailed as part of a crackdown on political opponents by then-president Pervez Musharraf. PTI grew rapidly over the two decades, and is now one of the major political forces in Pakistan. In the 2013 elections it overtook the PPP to become the official opposition party in the provinces of Punjab and Sindh.  In the 2018 election Khan's party went up against the ruling PML, whose former leader Nawaz Sharif was removed from office as Prime Minister over corruption charges in 2017 and later jailed. The election campaign has been marred by violence, delays in ballot counting and claims of vote rigging. A suicide bombing killed 31 people near a polling station in Quetta, capital of the Baluchistan province. Khan declared victory in the election on 26 July 2018, but looked unlikely to hit the majority of seats needed to form a solo government, meaning he would have to look to form a coalition.  Who is Imran Khan's wife? In the 1970s and 80s, Khan had an image as a playboy. He was often seen partying at London nightclubs, and was linked to a series of socialites and minor aristocrats. His first marriage, in May 1995, was to journalist and documentary producer Jemima Goldsmith - daughter of finance tycoon Sir James Goldsmith. Jemima converted to Islam before their wedding, and they married in a short ceremony in Paris. They had two sons together, Sulaiman Isa and Kasim. The pair divorced in June 2004, with Khan saying: my political life made it difficult for her to adapt to life in Pakistan.  His second marriage came in January 2015 to British-Pakistani journalist Reham Khan, but the pair announced their divorce just nine months later. Khan's political party confirmed in February 2018 that he had married for the third time, this time to his spiritual advisor Bushra Manika.

title: dundee people all aboard thehms unicornfor family fun
story: Swashbuckling pirates stormed the HMS Unicorn as people of all ages turned out for the vessel’s summer family fun day.Youngsters dressed up and got the chance to meet unofficial mascot Pirate Bob.Children also had their faces painted and took part in sand art activities.There was even a special curator’s tour of the Music of Maritime Life.Billy Rough, education officer at the Unicorn, said: “It was such a fantastic day.“It was incredibly busy despite it being a glorious sunny day. We were delighted to have live music courtesy of Big Noise Douglas and a motley crew of pirates from Medieval Methil Re-enactment Society entertained families.“Pirate Bob was, of course, on hand to entertain kids with lots of pirate games.“Look out for our next family fun day in October.”The next fun day will take place on October 20.

title: dundee people fans dress to impress for 80s rewind
story: It was fun in the sun all the way for the thousands of 1980s fans who enjoyed a bumper weekend of music at Rewind Scotland.As temperatures at Scone Palace soared to the mid 20s the hits of the decade just kept coming.The spectacle kicked off with the Skids on Saturday afternoon followed by a raft of stars including Bob Geldof and his Boomtown Rats, Bonnie Tyler, UB40 and Midge Ure before headline act Status Quo rounded the weekend off in true headbanging style.And as ever the Scottish crowd didn’t let the side down with plenty of neon lycra on show and hundreds of wacky outfits in keeping with the event.

title: dundee people gymnasts take a successful tumble
story: A number of local gymnasts enjoyed success at the NDP British Championships in Nottingham.Five members of Dundee Gymnastics Club 2K travelled to the championships which saw them tumbling down a 25-metre track giving a display of back flips, somersaults and other gravity-defying skills.Earlier last month saw seven of the clubs tumble squad head to Birmingham to represent Scotland in the NDP British semi-finals.Five of these gymnasts qualified, for of those returning with medals. Summer Geddes and Bethany Moss missing out on qualification but an amazing achievement to represent their country.First up to compete was little Katie Robb at NDP level 3 age 9-10, who improved her runs from the semi-finals to bag herself a silver medal.Next up was Lucy Stein who came a commendable 7th in NDP level 3 age 13+.The following day saw Sandy Robb, brother of Katie achieving the gold at NDP level 5 age 10-12 and hot on his heels was another club tumbler winning silver at the same level.Tegan Gaffney was last to compete at NDP level 5 age 15+. She didn’t disappoint bringing home a Bronze medal.Paul Carson, tumbling coach at the club, said: “The gymnasts had to show their speed, power and control when performing their routines. “I am proud as punch of what the team has achieved – it’s really fantastic.”

title: dundee people love at first sight and 60 years of marriage based on trust and happiness
story: Sixty years, 21,900 days, 525,000 hours.Last Thursday, these figures signified the length of time since Dundee couple Jim and Isabella Martin were married.Jim and Isabella Martin had been married.They first met at Camperdown Park in 1953 when Jim was 20 and Isabella was just 18.Isabella describes that chance encounter as “love at first sight”.“I was on a walk round Camperdown Park and Jim was there playing football with his friends,” she said.“The ball came rolling over and landed at my feet. When I saw Jim coming over, my heart was booming.“From then on our love flourished.”Five years later, after Jim proposed in Dublin, the happy couple were married at the High Kirk in Dundee on July 19 1958.In preparation for the big day, Jim lost a stone in weight, which he claims was due to all the worry.Isabella looked stunning in a white lace ballerina-style dress which she says still has “tomato stains down the front”.Jim and Isabella went on to have two sons and a daughter, and 10 grandchildren have followed.Isabella said: “Family has always been first and foremost in our life and to this day we still have a close bond with our family.“We enjoy cruises and have travelled the world, with our children occasionally joining us.”Sixty years is a long time but Jim and Isabella say the secret behind how long they have stayed together so long is very easy.“Our marriage has been based on love, trust and happiness,” said Isabella.“The problem with couples these days is that they just don’t trust each other.“For us it was love at first sight and to this day we still care so much about each other.”The Martins will be celebrating their anniversary with friends and family at Invercarse Hotel next week.

title: dundee people manjeet retires after 22 years
story: After 22 years of service, Manjeet Grill, co-ordinator at The Corner Dundee, a health and information service, is retiring.Starting out as a sessional worker encouraging young people from minority ethnic backgrounds to access citywide health services, she became an assistant project leader and then co-ordinator in 2011.Manjeet said: “Over the years I have been part of many changes at The Corner.“One of its successes is to be able to adapt, evolve and be responsive to young people’s needs. The Corner always has a multi-professional team which brings mixed skills to enable us to respond to the complexity of the needs of young people.”

title: dundee people pop up shop peps up charity
story: A pop-up ladies boutique in Broughty Ferry has raised several thousand pounds for charity.The shop in Gray Street has raised £7,600 for the Cystic Fibrosis Trust (CFT) in just two weeks.Cystic fibrosis is a genetic condition that affects the lungs and other organs.Morag Beckett, who set up the shop, said: “It’s been brilliant. We were lucky because the first week was Broughty Ferry gala week and the weather was glorious.“I want to thank people for their donations, for volunteering and those who came in and bought things.”Picture shows, from left, Hilary Carver, Laura Ross, piper Greg Beckett, Morag, CFT fundraising manager in Scotland Nicola Holland and Fiona Beckett.

title: dundee people scarlett has her gold and silver ticket
story: A business in jewellery is the golden (and silver) ticket for a happy career for Scarlett Erskine.She started her business – Scarlett Erskine Jewellery – in 2013 after falling in love with the craft during her first year of study at Duncan of Jordanstone.She said: “I did the general course at the university which gave you a chance to get a taster of courses that you could go on to do in the following years.“I tried textiles and jewellery but really enjoyed the craft of jewellery making so went on to study that for three years.“When I graduated I didn’t know how to go about creating my own business.“I visited Vanilla Ink Jewellery School, which was then based in Dundee, for guidance on how to turn my jewellery making into a business.”Now after five years based at Wasps Studio, Scarlett is still creating exquisitely designed pieces and also teaching others how to do it too.Scarlett added: “There are three main parts to my job. The first is my collections of jewellery which I design and make to be distributed to the shops that stock my designs up and down the country.“The second is my bespoke pieces.“This is where someone comes in with a design in mind or with a piece they want to be remodelled.“With my bespoke designs it is much more fun as I can be a bit more creative.“It can be a big responsibility as a lot of the time someone is grieving over the loss of a loved one and they want a piece to remember them by or they want a piece of their loved one’s jewellery reworked.“You can’t change it back, so it can be quite nerve-racking.“I have also incorporated people ashes into designs, so it can be a very emotional journey with my customer.“It is lovely that I can really help customers after the passing of a loved one with a piece that is incredibly sentimental.“The third part is teaching.“I have held workshops since the beginning. I think it makes the pieces more sentimental when someone has made the ring themselves.”After taking the plunge to work on her business full time only a year ago, Scarlett has urged anyone else in the same position to take that leap into self employment.“This business is my life and I love it. It is hard and scary to take that step but I am so glad I did it. I can really put my heart and soul into my pieces now.“I should have done it way sooner.”Scarlett’s workshops allow couples to have a personal touch at their wedding.A growing number of couples are visiting her studios to create their wedding rings – and some of those ready to get down on one knee are even coming to create a bespoke engagement ring for their other half.Scarlett said: “The workshops are incredibly popular and weddings are becoming a lot more DIY with couples wanting to be more hands on.“I love being part of the love story of making their rings.“We also hold hen parties a lot and brides love to come in and make matching silver rings with their bridesmaids.“It is a lot of fun.”

title: dundee people spar customers raise cash for good causes
story: The Spar store on Ballindean Road in the Douglas area of Dundee has been raising funds for a number of local good causes, including Brown Street Kennels, The Crescent in Whitfield and seven-year-old Garvie Winter, who is being treated for leukaemia.Kirsty Laing, from the store, said: “We do quite a lot of different things in the shop to raise money.“We sell a lot of books, mostly for 50p, which are really popular and we also get a lot of little things from customers who want to sell them to raise funds too. We have also held raffles in store.“We don’t focus on one charity but we like to give money to local causes.“We recently donated £50 to Garvie Winter and we have also worked with soldiers’ charities.“It is great to do what we can to help local people and we always take suggestions from our customers for charities to donate to.”

title: dundee united hand trial to former bayern munich and blackburn rovers star
story: Csaba Laszlo will have a look a player with a strong football pedigree as he tries to add to his attacking options at Dundee United.Today will see Austria Vienna reserve striker Toni Vastic arrive for a trial with the Tangerines.Now 25, Vastic spent time with both Blackburn Rovers and Bayern Munich’s second team in his younger days and also has experience of top flight football in his native Austria.And his father Ivica, though born in Croatia, won 50 caps for Austria between 1996 and 2008 as well as starring for the likes of Strum Graz and Austria Vienna, for whom he is now a youth coach.Csaba did not confirm Vastic is the player he was bringing over but did concede it was a striker from Vienna who is strong in the air and there is no doubt Vastic is that man.It was through the manager’s contacts in central Europe that the deal to bring him over for a tryout was done.“We are working to bring players in. I don’t make any secret that we are bringing someone in from Austria Vienna, a big striker, I can have a look at,” said Csaba.“We are talking with one other player and hope the signings can be made, the deals are done.“I hope by next week we will have a complete team.”United also hope to be boosted by the sight of another new striker, Craig Curran, making his debut when they complete their Betfred Cup campaign at Elgin City this Saturday.Curran was due back in training today after the dead leg that’s sidelined him for the past two weeks.If he completes his work over the next couple of days without suffering a reaction, he will be on duty up north and back on course to be ready for the league kick-off against Dunfermline next week.“We have been working on Craig and, if he is OK, he can get 45 minutes against Elgin and that would be good news.”Defender Callum Booth is another who has been in the wars but could be back on duty at the weekend.The former Partick Thistle man picked up a knock at Ross County last week and missed out against Alloa but could be ready over the next couple of days.

title: former dundee and dundee united star simon murray joins south african club
story: Hibernian have confirmed the departure of Simon Murray, who has joined South African outfit Bidvest Wits.The striker, 26, moved to Easter Road from Dundee United last summer and had a year remaining on his contract.Murray made 29 Hibs appearances, scoring 14 goals, including a winning strike against Edinburgh rivals Hearts.He spent the latter half of last term on loan at Dundee, netting three goals in 14 outings.Bidvest Wits won the South African Premier Division in 2017, but finished last term 13th in the 16-team league.After the deal was confirmed, Murray tweeted: “Thanks for allowing me to play for such a great club and meet some of the best people.“Won’t forget my goal in the derby in a hurry! But now time for another challenge and I am delighted to join Bidvest Wits.”

title: revealed scots legends primal scream to headline at va opening 2
story: Rock legends Primal Scream and Dundee singer Be Charlotte are among the acts set to perform at the festival marking the opening of the V&ampA Museum.The first-ever 3D Festival – free to Dundonians who register for tickets – will take place on September 14 and 15 before the venue’s much-anticipated opening.Up to 20,000 people from the city and beyond are expected to descend on Slessor Gardens for the historic event, organised by DF Concerts – the firm responsible for T in the Park and TRNSMT Festival.V&ampA bosses have also revealed that solo star Lewis Capaldi, ex-Danny Wilson frontman Gary Clark and the museum’s Young People’s Collective will also be performing over the two days.Be Charlotte will perform on both days, the first since wowing the crowds on the main stage at Carnival Fifty-Six last summer.Primal Scream will unveil a new collaboration with Turner Prize-nominee Jim Lambie for their performance.Other acts set to perform alongside Be Charlotte on Friday include Scots singer Tallia Storm, Dundee dance company Shaper/Caper and techno DJ Eclair Fifi.Saturday will see Dundee musicians St Martiins, Kashmir Crows and Andrew Wasylyk take to the stage.Family design workshops will be led by Abertay University with Beano Studios creating a special edition comic available to those attending the festival.The two-week online ballot to register for free Friday evening tickets opened at 10am today. Visit vandadundee.org for more information.
